reviewText: Take two hopeless I.T. nerds (one a slob and one a bespectacled social misfit), and add one pathologically lying people expert.  That's the setup for "The IT Crowd," a fun little workplace sitcom that sits on the other end of the comedy spectrum from "The Office" -- in particular, hardcore farce. The first three seasons are crammed full of pure weirdness and mild surreality, starting with simple workplace comedies and then piling on the weird.As the story begins, Jen (Katherine Parkinson) is hired by the deranged CEO Dernholm, whom she has told that she knows plenty about computers. Unfortunately, he doesn't plan to have her working on the levels that are full of "lots of sexy people, not doing much work, and having affairs."So he sends her down to the I.T. department, a filthy basement occupied only with "standard nerds" -- an embittered slob named Roy (Chris O'Dowd) and socially oblivious Moss (Richard Ayoade). Despite the fact that they keep the company from imploding, nobody appreciates them ("Have you tried turning it off and on again?"). Initially the guys loathe Jen and vice versa, but gradually they start to appreciate one another."The IT Crowd: Seasons 1, 2 & 3" has a few bumps in the road ("The Haunting of Bill Crouse" way overextends some of its jokes) but is overall a pretty solid sitcom -- think a more farcical version of "The Office" with a dash of "The Mighty Boosh." It even has Noel Fielding as the supremely freaky goth that lives down in the basement like a vampire (for the first two seasons).And it's got some great running jokes like Douglas Reynholm's ("I don't think I've ever looked in this drawer... WOW, a gun!") and the idiots who call IT because their computers are unplugged. But each episode has its own running gags: toe-deforming shoes, "manly" behavior, flaming bras, erotic calendars and Douglas offending the top five major world religions. And the dialogue is a big oozing bundle of hilarity ("I'm going to strain my personal potatoes throughout her premises!").The core three actors are all brilliant at their very different characters -- Parkinson (who looks like a slapstickier version of Gillian Anderson) is wonderful as a pathological liar and girly-girl with the worst office on Earth. O'Dowd is deliciously sloppy and resentful about the way the rest of the employees treat him (a necessary evil), and Ayoade is gloriously monotonic and clueless about real life.It has a couple weak episodes, but "The IT Crowd: Seasons 1, 2, and 3" is the funniest Britcom in years -- and thankfully, it's still going strong.
summary: Let me put on my slightly larger glasses

reviewText: This show is witty and has some of the funniest geek shows of all time. Get it. You'll love it. Do a YouTube search for great clips if you doubt me, then buy this and own it. It's fun to have. It's available on live streaming on Netflix right now... but I still like having them.
Title: N/A

reviewText: If not for Netflix streaming service, I likely would've never stumbled upon The IT Crowd.  The episodes get better and better as the writers and actors find their grooves and run with what works for the show, into seasons 2 and 3.The pokes at corporate culture are needed these days, and there's nothing better than well-done humor involving scenarios of misunderstanding that escalate into increasing levels of hilarity, when cast with such great, relatable actors. They all have flaws and remind of us of oursevles in some way, without resorting to mindless American reality television.American producers just don't get it, their sitcoms are shiny and spotless and controlled, corporate and only dip shamelessly into creative and truly witty or uncomfortable humor, but that is very rare.  They'd just assume toss you low cost reality TV.  After all, you have hundreds of options, but hardly anything on TV is worth anyone's time these days across the board.The IT Crowd's lack of popularity is a blessing, as are most highly visible media projects these days that are worthwhile.  It's completely unpretentious British humor that is extremely relatable in today's global corporate culture, where a growing mass of people are trying to survive and find meaning or logic or some happiness while spending the vast majority of their time doing unfulfilling, pointless jobs, for people that can't remember their names.Best comedy sitcom of this decade, and no one knows about it.  Fitting!
summary: Best comedy sitcom in a long time

reviewText: I also stumbled across this show on Netflix streaming.  I am a 40 year old woman and LOVE this show.  I think my husband and I have watched each episode three or four times.  It just does not get old.  Even my kids love this show-  though not all of the episodes are appropriate for kids.  I keep waiting for Netflix to get the other seasons.  We have even gotten my husband's parents and my parents hooked on this show.  It is laugh out loud, bring tears to your eyes comic genius.
